content.description:
Start from a high LH edge and a RH sidepull, get your feet up and match hands and then it's easy to the top.

Being tall helps on this one as the start is very reachy.
content.location:
Far left side of the west face between

Retro

and

Voyager

.

content.description: Start at an obvious v-slot and work a thin black sidepull with a high left foot up to a good RH edge. Once the good hold is reached with feet high it's easy to the top.
content.location:
Left side of the west face between

Ultraviolet

and

Nebula

.

content.description:
Located on the far left side of the west face, just left of Ultraviolet (V2) and immediately right of the walk-off for the boulder.

Start off a small block on the left and grab grainy edges while getting your feet established onto the face. Work up and left for a good hold on the arete, get your feet up and then make a long move to the lip for an incut but hollow rail which is mantled to finish.

This problem is found on the south face of the Asteroid Boulder about 10' right of

Ceres

and around and left from the thin crack/seam of

Peabrain

at an obvious left-facing flake.

Match hands on the flake, pull onto a small ledge and then lieback up the flake passing a steep bit with smears for the feet (crux) until possible to grab the top of the flake. From the top of the flake run your feet up the face and finish with an easy mantle.

This problem is unnamed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but given the name Pioneer to honor the first spacecraft to travel through the asteroid belt of our solar system.

More inforation about Pioneer here

.

Pull into the undercut finger crack/seam and work your feet up as you lieback your way along this technical and enticing problem. Not a highball but exciting enough near the top with your feet pasted high. Quality.
content.protection: pad, spotter (position your pad(s) left of the crack).
content.location: South face of the boulder and the left of two seams.

content.description:
Start as for

Peabrain

and traverse right or start direct and power over the bulge using the seam/crack to rounded finish.
content.location:
The obvious seam just right of

Peabrain

.

content.description:
You'll find this fun problem on the west face of the Asteroid Boulder between Voyager (V2) on the left and

Ceres

(5.6) on the right at an obvious left-facing flake system.

Grab a left-facing flake, high-step onto smears and then lieback the flake up and left until possible to reach high to some creaky flakes and top out. This is a fun problem with good movement for the grade (5.8).

Refer to picture topo under Pea Brain V4.

There is also a sit-start from good obvious holds under Pea Brain, traversing right into Mighty Dog. Not sure of the grade.

At about 5.7, another nice route on this boulder. Step high and reach for the shallow crack, climb it to the top.  Similar in height and quality to its easy neighbors to the left.

Not in the Miramontes guide, but a fun climb after you've made the trek out there.
content.location: South face of the Asteroid Boulder, easily visible shallow, vertical crack between Pioneer and Peabrain.

content.description: This challenging thin face problem starts off a small block at the base and works up the face above using marginal handholds with good feet. The finish is a bit reachy which might cause shorter climbers to find this problem slightly harder than indicated.
content.location: Far right side of the east face.

content.description:
Around and right from

Nebula

, on the other side of the flake that contains that is problem is this right-facing flake to a huge black jug. The problem

Pioneer

is found about 10' right at a left-facing flake.

Grab the flake high, get your feet onto a horizontal and then work the flake higher as you smear your feet over a slight bulge to reach the obvious jugs before mantling over the top - fun!

This problem is unnamed in the Joshua Tree Bouldering Guide but given the name Ceres here due to it's resemblence to the symbol (a sickle with a crossbar at the bottom) for that dwarf planet/asteroid -

click here for more information about Ceres

.
